channel.title: Comments on: Tips and Tricks to Make SQL Server Management Studio Awesome
channel.description: A Technical Community for IT Professionals

item.title: By: Looking for dark theme for SSMS 2011
item.dc:creator: Looking for dark theme for SSMS 2011
item.description:
For those looking for dark theme note that this theme does not work on SSMS 2011. SSMS refuses to import the settings file.
https://mikesdatawork.wordpress.com/2016/06/04/how-to-use-mikes-ssms-2016-theme/
item.content:encoded:
For those looking for dark theme note that this theme does not work on SSMS 2011. SSMS refuses to import the settings file.

https://mikesdatawork.wordpress.com/2016/06/04/how-to-use-mikes-ssms-2016-theme/

item.title: By: Here's a dark SSMS Theme (Monokai)
item.dc:creator: Here's a dark SSMS Theme (Monokai)
item.description:
How about a dark theme for SSMS. This is based on the Monokai theme, and is super nice on the eyes. What a great find.
I just loaded it. Very nice. It's called Mikes SSMS 2016 Theme.
https://mikesdatawork.wordpress.com/2016/06/04/how-to-use-mikes-ssms-2016-theme/
You can download it if you want, and just load it into SSMS. The guy has a tutorial where you click.
item.content:encoded:
How about a dark theme for SSMS. This is based on the Monokai theme, and is super nice on the eyes. What a great find.

I just loaded it. Very nice. It’s called Mikes SSMS 2016 Theme.

https://mikesdatawork.wordpress.com/2016/06/04/how-to-use-mikes-ssms-2016-theme/

You can download it if you want, and just load it into SSMS. The guy has a tutorial where you click.

item.title: By: Jes Borland
item.dc:creator: Jes Borland
item.description: When you write the SQL query from the application, write it as SELECT address, city, id, name FROM tablename.
item.content:encoded: When you write the SQL query from the application, write it as SELECT address, city, id, name FROM tablename.

item.title: By: charles theman
item.dc:creator: charles theman
item.description:
Hello,
Good Day.
Newbie here, and I would like to ask for assistance on our sql.
Please help, how do we make the default tables on mssql 2008 r2 to be on alphabetical order?
like for example: fields on table:
name address id city
when we tried to access it on different software it should display like:
address city id name
Thank you and God Bless.
item.content:encoded:
Hello,

Good Day.

Newbie here, and I would like to ask for assistance on our sql.

Please help, how do we make the default tables on mssql 2008 r2 to be on alphabetical order?

like for example:
fields on table:

name
address
id
city

when we tried to access it on different software it should display like:

address
city
id
name

Thank you and God Bless.

item.title: By: Chandrashekar K
item.dc:creator: Chandrashekar K
item.description:
We also use Oracle database and use Oracle-SQL-Developer as IDE which is similar to SSMS. Oracle-SQL-Developer also has feature to filter the database objects. However it has an advantage that if you apply a filer, close the tool and open it again, the filter values stay and not get cleared automatically. You manually need to clear or change it. I search whether same feature is available in SSMS but did not find any.
If anyone knows how to enable the feature or know any workaround please let me know.
Thanks in advance. Chandrashekar K
item.content:encoded:
We also use Oracle database and use Oracle-SQL-Developer as IDE which is similar to SSMS. Oracle-SQL-Developer also has feature to filter the database objects. However it has an advantage that if you apply a filer, close the tool and open it again, the filter values stay and not get cleared automatically. You manually need to clear or change it. I search whether same feature is available in SSMS but did not find any.

If anyone knows how to enable the feature or know any workaround please let me know.

Thanks in advance.
Chandrashekar K

item.title: By: aj
item.dc:creator: aj
item.description: Instead of dragging columns individually, click on columns and drag it to query window. You will get all the columns comma separated.
item.content:encoded: Instead of dragging columns individually, click on columns and drag it to query window. You will get all the columns comma separated.

item.title: By: Jes Borland
item.dc:creator: Jes Borland
item.description: I don't know of a way to have the brackets not appear. However, that helps if any of your column, table, view, or stored procedure names have spaces or punctuation in them!
item.content:encoded: I don’t know of a way to have the brackets not appear. However, that helps if any of your column, table, view, or stored procedure names have spaces or punctuation in them!

item.title: By: Wyannd
item.dc:creator: Wyannd
item.description: Hi Im newbie, just started studying SQL server 2012. When I drop and drag columns from the object browser I get square brackets: SELECT[custid][companyname][contactname] Is there setting that I will get commas without spaces :SELECT custid,companyname,contactname
item.content:encoded:
Hi Im newbie, just started studying SQL server 2012. When I drop and drag columns from the object browser I get square brackets: SELECT[custid][companyname][contactname]
Is there setting that I will get commas without spaces :SELECT custid,companyname,contactname

item.title: By: Aalamjeet Rangi
item.dc:creator: Aalamjeet Rangi
item.content:encoded:
Very nice compilation!

I wrote a post about the status-bar-color feature earlier. The SSMS implementation is not perfect but still we shall be thankful for what we get 🙂

item.title: By: Naomi Nosonovsky
item.dc:creator: Naomi Nosonovsky
item.description: Thanks, Jes. I found it also in SSMSBoost which I had installed. So, I installed it and was able to get it back (re-created the script for bkp)
item.content:encoded: Thanks, Jes. I found it also in SSMSBoost which I had installed. So, I installed it and was able to get it back (re-created the script for bkp)
